characters: A GORGEOUSLY MANICURED GARDEN LINED WITH MAJESTIC TREES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dank semi-basement apartment. KI-WOO, 24, runs from cor to corner searching desperately for a Wi-Fi signal. Vario networks pop up, but they’re all password-protected.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: NO. Not you too “iptime.” Ki-Jung! Upstairs neighbor finally locked up his Wi-Fi.

dialogues.speaker: ADJACENT ROOM --
dialogues.text: Lying on the floor of the narrow room, KI-JUNG, 23, barel moves her lips -- ‘Fuck.’

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Try ‘123456789.’ Then try it backwards.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: No luck.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ROOM --
dialogues.text: Also lying on the floor, CHUNG-SOOK, 49, the mother, scof their collective misery.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do if someone calls me? What if it’s a job? Hey, Ki-Tek! She kicks KI-TEK, 49, who is sleeping at her feet. CHUNG-SOOK (CONT’D) I know you’re awake, asshole. Care to comment?

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: (wiping his drool) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our phones have been suspended for weeks, and now the neighbors have shut us out. What’s your plan? She kicks him again. CHUNG-SOOK (CONT’D) What are you going to do about it? What's the plan, genius? She treats Ki-Tek like shit, but it doesn’t bother him. H rises with the most serene, enlightened smile, then plods to the --

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM SLASH KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Where he removes a bag of white bread from the sad, empty fridge. The bread is nearly gone too. Only the ends remai Ki-Tek takes a piece and picks off the moldy parts. He ch on the bread as he watches his son’s Wi-Fi dance.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Son, if one seeks Wi-Fi-- He raises his hand high. KI-TEK (CONT’D) One must reach into the heavens. Up.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Yes, Father. Ki-Woo raises the phone high as he heads into the --

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: The bathroom is long and narrow and has a raised ‘altar’ far end where the toilet sits. The odd placement is necessitated by the semi-basement’s lower position in rel to the septic tank. Ki-Woo walks in and climbs onto the toilet seat. He conti to fish for a signal when --

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You got it? Ki-Jung barges in and walks over with her phone held up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see it? “coffeenara_2G”. I guess it’s a new coffee joint. Must be nearby.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: I’m not getting shit.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Get up closer. Ki-Jung climbs onto the altar and squeezes next to Ki-Woo siblings look ridiculous. Head touching the ceiling. Hudd on top of the toilet seat. Chung-Sook pops in.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: No text from Pizza Time? 2,000 more boxes and it’s payday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family sits among piles of UNASSEMBLED PIZZA BOXES an folds them in silence. The crunch of cardboard is the onl sound as the cheap Pizza Time logo comes in and goes out foreground. They hear a truck rattling closer. Through the window, th see a STREET FUMIGATION TRUCK spewing gas as it passes by fog rolls closer to the window.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (to Ki-Woo) Close the window.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Leave it. Free fumigation. Get rid of the damn crickets. Ki-Woo, who was about to close the window, sits back down The FOG quickly envelops the family as they continue to f It’s rather poignant. A family braving through tear-induc fumes just to make a meager living.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: (gasps) Shit!

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (coughing) I told you to close it!

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Fuck me.  4. Ki-Tek continues folding despite his red, bulging face. H desperately holds back his cough. Ki-Woo goes to the bathroom and returns moments later wit phone. He shows the family a GIF he downloaded.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Watch. If we all fold like this girl, we might even get paid today. The GIF shows “The World’s Fastest Pizza Box Folder,” a W GIRL with dazzling box-folding skills. She’s fast. The family watches in awe. Inspired by the clip, they sta folding with renewed vigor. Ki-Tek also picks up speed, but he lacks the dexterity of others. He’s getting more and more sloppy.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. SEMI-BASEMENT
dialogues.text: Through the half-open door, we see the female PIZZA SHOP standing outside the entrance. Quirky appearance. Pizza T T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Look at this for example. This shitty folding job here. The Owner shows Chung-Sook a botched corner. PIZZA SHOP OWNER (CONT’D) One out of four. One-fourth of the boxes are unusable. One out of four? The family all look at Ki-Tek. He just smiles. Innocent as ever.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: (sighs) Still, you can’t cut ten percent from my pay. That’s too much.

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo helps a MAN load boxes into a van. Ki-Tek looks out from the apartment window, watching Chun squabble with the Pizza Shop Owner.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: I should pay even less considering the number of botched boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were barely making anything to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Look. It’s not that simple. Each ruined box exponentially tarnishes our brand’s image.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Your “brand”? You only have two stores in Seoul. Fuck this--

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: What did you say? Ki-Woo quickly steps in, diffusing the situation with an smile.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: It’s that kid, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: The part-timer at your shop. He went MIA, didn’t he? During such a crucial time too. You have a large group order from The Love of Christ Church. That’s why you and your husband are out here working your bottoms off.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: How do you know that? Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: That kid, he’s my friend.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Totally unreliable. Not-so- stellar reputation.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I understand you’re upset. Ten percent? Fine, we accept. That’s completely within your authority. However--

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: However what?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Would you consider hiring a new employee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire the loser who bailed on you. The Owner just stares at the smiling siblings. What the h are these people?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I can come in for an interview tomorrow. What would be a good time for you?

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Wait. Hold on. I need to think about this-- The Owner senses a trap and tries to get out of it. She t out a few bills from her fanny pack and starts counting o one. The family all stare. It’s been a while since they’ve see money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ‘master bedroom’ next to the entrance. Wall adorned w pictures of a young Chung-Sook competing at a national tr and field championship as a student athlete. A SHOT PUTTE Great upper body glimpsed through tight uniform. No pictu of Ki-Tek. Early evening. It’s darker. The four family members are gathered around a table filled with various store-bought

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: What a special occasion. The four of us gathered here to celebrate the partial reactivation of our phones as well as our son’s upcoming job interview with a national franchise. Ki-Tek tries to deliver a heartfelt speech like a TV patr but severely lacks the gravitas. Chung-Sook and Ki-Jung a already drinking their beers.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Cheers!

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: To family! (re: window) That son of a bitch. It’s not even dark yet!  The family turns to see -- A DRUNK MAN teetering toward the semi-basement window. Their faces slowly fill with dread.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: How many times did I tell you? We need to put up a “No Urinating” sign.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: It'll make them want to do it even more. It’s psychology.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (to Ki-Woo) Go yell at him or something!

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: It’s not the right timing-- The Drunk Man hasn’t unzipped his pants, still hovering uncertainly in the dark corner. KI-WoO (CONT’D) (hesitates) I need to catch him in the act.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Isn’t it fucking obvious? Just kick him out!

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (to herself) I hate this place. Ki-Woo gets up, still unsure, when --

dialogues.speaker: HEY, MISTER
dialogues.text: A VOICE booms from afar. Behind the Drunk Man, we see a handsome, well-built young man climbing off a fancy scoot This is MIN-HYUK, 24. He walks over with a LARGE BOX in h hands.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Is that Min-Hyuk?

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: It is. Ki-Woo is surprised to see Min-Hyuk, who continues to yel the would-be public urinater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you’re doing? You think this is a public toilet?

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK MAN
dialogues.text: I, uh--

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: What are you looking at! Cowed by Min-Hyuk’s presence, the Drunk Man quickly skeda away. Ki-Tek taps Ki-Woo on the shoulder. A smitten apartment.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Your friend has mucho cajones.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: It’s that college student glow. Look at that confidence.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Which Ki-Woo obviously doesn’t have. Ki-Jung admires Min-Hyuk as he walks over to the He enters.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: How are you, Mr. and Mrs. Kim!

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Min-Hyuk! Good to see you, son!

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: What's with the surprise appearance?

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: I texted you. (to Ki-Jung) Hey, Ki-Jung. Ki-Jung smiles shyly as she nods. Ki-Woo searches through his text messages.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: We could have met somewhere else. You didn’t have to come all this way.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: I brought this.  Min-Hyuk shows Ki-Woo the box. MIN-HYUK (CONT’D) It’s heavy so I had to bring it on my bike.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: What’s this? Ki-Jung lifts the flap to see a UNIQUELY SHAPED STONE and wooden display stand inside.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: (to Ki-Tek) When I told my grandfather I was going to see Ki-Woo, he gave me this.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Whoa. Ki-Tek picks up the large stone. KI-TEK (CONT’D) This is a precious viewing stone. Is this an abstract specimen?

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: You know your stones, Mr. Kim. Pop-Pop’s been collecting viewing stones since his academy days. Our house is literally filled with these things -- living room, study, basement... This one is supposed to bring luck. And money.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: How perfect for us. Symbolic.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Yes, how serendipitous. Please send him our sincere regards.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: (to herself) He should’ve brought food. Ki-Jung stabs Chung-Sook with her finger. Fortunately Min didn’t hear. As a beaming Ki-Tek continues to show off useless stone t  10. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Min-Hyuk and Ki-Woo sit at a portable table outside the s drinking soju and chasing it with chips. Min-Hyuk’s expen foreign scooter is parked behind him. It visually clashes the old grocery store and run-down alley.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: I had to bring that stupid rock, but it was nice to see your folks. They look good.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: They’re not as good as they look. They’re all jobless.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: Ki-Jung’s at home too? She doesn’t take college prep classes?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: It’s not that she doesn’t want to. She can’t. Ki-Woo downs a shot of soju. Min-Hyuk looks at Ki-Woo. He has something to say. He tak out his phone and shows Ki-Woo -- A picture of a brightly smiling TEENAGE GIRL. High school uniform. Innocent.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: Cute, right?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Is that her? The girl you’re tutoring? Min-Hyuk nods.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: Park Da-Hae. A sophomore. I want you to tutor her. Take over for me as her English teacher.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: That makes no sense.

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: Her family’s loaded. The gig pays really well.  11. That gets Ki-Woo’s attention. He looks at the picture aga MIN-HYUK (CONT’D) She’s a good kid. I want you to look after her until I come back from the study-abroad program.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: You have plenty of friends at school. Why do you want a high- school grad to teach your prized student?

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: Why do you think? I shudder just thinking about those female- starved engineering students drooling around her like hungry wolves. It’s revolting. Ki-Woo studies Min-Hyuk.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: (laughs) You like her, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: (nods ) I’m serious about her. I’m going to ask her out in two years, once she’s in college. I want you to take care of her while I’m gone. I trust you.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I appreciate the trust, but you want me to pretend I’m a college student?

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo, think about it. How many times have you taken the college entrance exam? Twice before your military service and twice after -- a grand total of four times. Grammar, vocabulary, composition, speaking. You’re an English master. Far more qualified as a tutor than I am. Better than those spoiled college brats who drown their brain cells in booze everyday.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: That may be true but-- You think the family would accept me? I’m not even a college student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll embellish a little. You’1ll be fine. You’1ll have my recommendation. And the mother is a bit-- 12. Min-Hyuk picks up his glass to drink when he suddenly bec thoughtful. He smiles. MIN-HYUK (CONT’D) She’s simple. Young. And simple.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: (English) Simple? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MIN-HYUK
dialogues.text: (English) I don’t know. Just simple. Min-Hyuk and Ki-Woo start conversing in English for no re They’re fluent. MIN-HYUK (CONT’D) I hear Ki-Jung is handy with Photoshop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Jung is working at the computer, clicking the mouse an tapping various keyboard shortcuts with dizzying speed. like a magician. On the monitor is a document -- “Certificate of Enrollment.” With laser focus, Ki-Jung refines the edges of the red certification seal.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: This is amazing. How come you keep failing the art school exam?

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Shut up, dickwad. The siblings work discreetly in the corner of the large internet café.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Take your time. (looking around) We should hold off on the printing until the place clears out. She's  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Tek is on the floor laying his head on the viewing sto He admires the freshly printed enrollment certificate.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Look at this. There should be a major for document forgery at Seoul National University. Ki- Jung would be top of the class.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Shut up and wish the boy good luck for his interview.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: My son-- Ki-Tek sits up. KI-TEK (CONT’D) I’m so proud of you. A slightly awkward and embarrassing moment. They all know Woo did nothing to be proud of. Ki-Woo finishes touching up his hair in front of the mirr He picks up the fake certificate.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I don’t consider this a crime. No. Because I plan on going to this school next year.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: That’s my son. Man with a plan.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I’m just using some of their administrative services in advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet road snaking up the hill of a wealthy neighborhoo High walls. Not a pedestrian in sight. Except Ki-Woo, who consults the map on his phone as he walks up the hill, ba strapped. He looks around. Walks faster.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo stands in front of the gate, which is at the top o steep stairway. He waits through the MELODIC DOORBELL unt VOICE finally answers. The voice is middle-aged, female.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (SPEAKER)
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Mrs. Park? Hi, I’m Min-Hyuk’s friend--

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (SPEAKER)
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. Please come in. CLANK. The gate is unlocked, and Ki-Woo walks into --

dialogues.speaker: A GORGEOUSLY MANICURED GARDEN LINED WITH MAJESTIC TREES
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo stops midway and admires the trees, overcome with

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Quite a view, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Mrs. Park, pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I’m the housekeeper. Please follow me. MUN-KWANG, 45, fashionable and poised enough to be mistak the owner, leads Ki-Woo inside.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Stunning garden.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: The inside is even more stunning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo carefully follows Mun-Kwang inside. Indeed, the interior is stunning. But not excessive. The furniture an decorations are all tasteful.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: Do you know Namgoong Hyunja? The famous Korean-French architect? Ki-woo is blank.  15. MUN-KWANG (CONT’D) This used to be his house. He built it. KI-WwoO I see.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: Now it’s just Da-Hae’s house. Mun-Kwang stops just short of the fabulous living room overlooking the garden, arriving at the equally fabulous spacious --

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN / DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: She seats Ki-Woo at the large wooden table. MUN-KWANG (CONT’D) Please wait here. I’11 get Mrs. Park. Mun-Kwang exits, and Ki-Woo is left alone in silence. He quietly gets up and looks around. There’s some kind of AVANT-GARDE ART hanging on the wall. to it, he sees a typical Korean FAMILY PORTRAIT taken at studio. Ki-Woo walks over to the window, which overlooks the back He sees -- A WOMAN dozing off at the patio table. English magazine o on the table. Head tilted comically. Only her soft white is visible. This is YON-KYO, 41. Mun-Kwang walks over and CLAPS her hands loudly next to Y Kyo’s ears. Yon-Kyo sucks her drool in and slowly raises her head. We their muffled voices through the window. MUN-KWANG (CONT’D) The tutor is here.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: What do you think of him?

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: (smiles) I don’t know, but he’s handsome.  12 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yon-Kyo sits with Ki-Woo at the dining table. She pulls o the fake certificate halfway, glimpses at it, then puts i in. Ki-Woo is nervous. Even the DOG, cradled in Yon-Kyo’s arm watching him. Panting. Disapproving.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I don’t care about papers. I only wanted to see you because you were recommended by Min-Hyuk. I guess you two are good friends. Ki-Woo listens quietly. YON-KYO (CONT’D) I’m sure you know better than I do, but Min-Hyuk is just the most brilliant human being. I don’t even care about the grades. Da- Hae and I absolutely adored him. Do you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: We just loved him so much. I wanted him to stay with Da-Hae through her college exams next year, but now he’s leaving to study abroad and I’m suddenly left without a tutor. I mean, what am I supposed to do? Ki-Woo listens, respectful. YON-KYO (CONT’D) Excuse my bluntness, but I just don’t see the point of hiring someone unless he’s as utterly outstanding as Min-Hyuk, you know? Mun-Kwang sneaks a glance at Ki-Woo as she brings coffee to the table, checking him out. CLINK. She sets it down loudly in front of Ki-Woo. YON-KYO (CONT’D) I guess what I wanted to ask was -- Would it be okay if I sat in for today’s class? I want to see the whole thing. Judge for myself. I would like to see your -- methods.  13 14 17. KI-WwoO Uh...

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (English) Is that okay with you? Yon-Kyo suddenly blurts out a question in English. Her En is terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo follows Yon-Kyo up the large, oppressive staircase trying his best not look at her conspicuously swaying hip arrives on the second floor where he sees -- A long hallway with several doors on each side. INT. MANSION - DA-HAE’S ROOM - LATE AFTERNOON 14 A large, pretty room. Yon-Kyo and her dog are sitting on bed watching Ki-Woo. The attention doesn’t bother Ki-Woo, who is calmly focuse DA-HAE as she works through a practice test.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Are you sure about question 14?

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Is it wrong?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I’m asking you. What does your gut say? Do you think number 14 is right? Da-Hae shrinks. KI-WOoO (CONT’D) You were working on other questions before you came back to 14. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: Yes. Ki-Woo suddenly snatches Da-Hae’s wrist, shocking both Da and her mom. He presses his thumb gently and feels her pu like doctor.  18.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: If this was a real test and number 14 was the first question, you would’ve been in trouble from the start. He presses harder. KI-WOoO (CONT’D) See? You pulse is irregular. Your heart doesn’t lie. Da-Hae turns bright red. Yon-Kyo is speechless, either appalled or in awe. KI-WOoO (CONT’D) What are you supposed to do ina test? You move forward. You need to seize the flow. The rhythm. If not, you’re screwed. I don’t care about question number 14. I only care about how you seize the flow. How you conquer the test as a whole. You get it? Da-Hae is quiet. KI-WoO (CONT’D) A test is all about confidence. (English) Attitude. Stunned silence. Ki-Woo finally lets go of Da-Hae’s wrist revealing a round, pink spot where he held her. Ki-Woo looks over at Yon-Kyo. She’s completely floored. KI-WoO (CONT’D) I know. You were angry. Frustrated. You worked so hard. Studied until your nose bled. But your test scores weren’t improving. You keep asking yourself, ‘What am I doing wrong?’ That triggers something in Da-Hae. Emotions swell, and he pupils tremble. KI-WoO (CONT’D) I’m here to prepare you for the real thing. I’m not here to help you learn. I’m here to help you score.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a thick money envelope being handed to Ki-Woo.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I’1l pay you each month on this day. As for the lesson, I was thinking three times a week? Monday, Wednesday, Friday?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: That sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: It’s a little more than what Min- Hyuk used to get. Cost of living and so forth.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Thank you. As Ki-Woo puts away the envelope, Mun-Kwang brings over a plate. She’s noticeably friendlier than before.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (to Mun-Kwang) I guess it’s time to get to know each other. Mr. Kevin will be Da- Hae’s English teacher.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: Of course! Mr. Kevin, you let me know if you need anything at all during your lessons -- snacks, drinks, whatever.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Feel free to pester her if you need anything in this house. She’s the expert. She knows it better than I do. They continue exchanging pleasantries when -- THUNK. A PLASTIC ARROW flies in and hits Mun-Kwang’s shou When Ki-Woo looks over -- It’s a boy in a Native American costume about to shoot an arrow. This is DA-SONG, 10, the youngest Park. YON-KYO (CONT’D) Da-Song! Behave yourself. We have a guest!  20. Da-Song doesn’t care. He continues shooting. Mun-Kwang is used to the antics. She picks up an arrow an rubs it in her armpit.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: (silly laugh) Armpit attack!

dialogues.speaker: DA-SONG
dialogues.text: No!! It stinks! Da-Song plucks a TOY AXE from his belt and starts running ‘slow motion’ toward Mun-Kwang. He screams like a warrior Mun-Kwang does the same, flailing in fake slow motion. Th make quite a pair.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (sighs) I apologize. Our son is a little --unique.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Unique is good.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: He has trouble focusing. ADHD. We signed him up for the Cub Scouts hoping the discipline would help, but he’s become an even bigger weirdo. Now he’s obsessed with Indians--

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: (laughs) The Scouts have roots in American Indian culture, so he has the right idea.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: You were a Scout too?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Yes, I learned a lot as a Scout.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Look how fine you turned out. What's wrong with him? (then, serious) He’s actually an art prodigy, you know. Did you see the drawings? (re: pictures on the wall) Those are his.  16 21. Ki-Woo turns toward the AVANT-GARDE DRAWINGS on the wall. gazes for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: A lot of symbolism. Such strong point of view.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Right? Strong. I knew you would get it, Mr. Kevin. Ki-Woo takes a couple of steps back and admires the drawi with a serious face.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I see. It’s an interpretation of a chimpanzee.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: It’s a self-portrait. Awkward. Crickets chirp as Da-Song and Mun-Kwang continue battle it out in the background.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Of course. Us grown-ups are too jaded to see true genius.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: That must be why. We’ve gone through dozens of art teachers. They never last more than a month. Of course Da-Song is a bit much to handle. Ki-Woo nods. Yon-Kyo has come to see him out with the dog in her arms. The gate opens. Ki-Woo begins to step out when he stops.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Actually... Mrs. Park.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Someone just happened to come to my mind. Her name is--  17 22. Through Yon-Kyo’s POV, we see the back of Ki-Woo’s head a seemingly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tries to remember. KI-WOoO (CONT’D) Girl’s Generation. The girl group. What was her name -- the one who started the jewelry brand?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Jessica?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Right! Jessica. My cousin has a school friend named Jessica. I don’t know her Korean name. She studied applied arts at Illinois State and recently moved back to Korea.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Ah, Illinois State. What about her?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: She also tutors, and she’s known to have a very unique approach to teaching art. Most of all, she knows how to handle kids.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (interested) Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: She’s a bit of a celebrity in tutoring circles. Her style isa little unorthodox, but it still gets kids into good art schools.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: She sounds fantastic. I’m so curious.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Would you be interested in meeting her? She’s very busy so I’m not sure if I’1l be able to get an appointment--—

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Jessica? (laughs) Why Jessica. So tacky. 17  18 23. Ki-Jung is getting her hair done at the neighborhood shop Ki-Woo is sucking on a popsicle on the sofa behind her.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: It has a nice ring. Anyhow. She’s a nice lady. Young. Not the brightest tool in the shed. The money is good, and most of all, she’s a ‘believer.’

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: She’s religious? TRACK BACK TO REVEAL -- Chung-Sook and Ki-Tek sitting nex Ki-Jung, also getting their hairs trimmed.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: No, it’s just-- She tends to trust people rather easily. They become thoughtful. Ki-Tek breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: She sounds like a great lady.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Yeah. The family members all nod. A strange excitement appears their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo and Ki-Jung both take a deep breath in front of th gate. Ki-Jung looks like a completely new person with sho stylish hair and makeup. Ki-Woo is about to ring the doorbell when Ki-Jung stops h She suddenly starts clapping a beat with her hands.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (singing) Jessica, only child, Chicago Illinois / My classmate Jin-Mo is cousin of Kevin She sings her ‘bio’ to the tune of a catchy Korean oldie. Woo joins. Silly. Ridiculous. But you can sense a real sibling bond.  19 20 24. Finally Ki-Woo presses the button, and the DOORBELL rings throughout the quiet neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Da-Song at the bottom of the stairs peeking insid kitchen where -- Yon-Kyo is interviewing Ki-Jung. They talk quietly. Forma Serious. Ki-Woo sits a few feet away. Da-Hae tiptoes down from second floor and sees Da-Song pe She flicks his forehead and sends him upstairs. She then looks inside the kitchen herself. She focuses on Jung, scrutinizing, suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I should go upstairs for my lesson. I’11 let you two talk. (to Ki-Jung) Jessica, nice meeting you. Ki-Woo gets up and nods to Ki-Jung. KI-WOoO (CONT’D) I’1l see you next time. Ki-Jung also stands up, cordial.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Thank you, Kevin. Da-Hae sees Ki-Woo coming and runs back up the stairs. INT. MANSION - DA-HAE’S ROOM - EVENING 20 Da-Hae hurries back to her desk and pretends to work on h problems. The door opens, and Ki-Woo enters. He sits next to Da-Hae

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Where did we leave off? Number

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: You know--

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: You know it’s all an act, right? My brother.  25.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: It’s all fake. Acting all bizarro. Like he’s a crazed artist. He’s a big fraud.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Da-Song?

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: You know, like he would stop in the middle of the street and pretend he was struck by a sudden inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: (laughs) Randomly stare up at the clouds and ponder the shapes? Something like that?

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: Exactly! He’s the worst! And he acts like he can’t behave normal. Like he’s completely perplexed. Makes me want to puke.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: So Da-Song is a fraud. What does that have to do with your English problems? Dae-Hae pouts when Ki-Woo suddenly returns to tutor mode.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Good. Now those were all great descriptions of Da-Song. Why don’t we use them to compose a paragraph in English? You must use the word ‘pretend’ at least twice. Ki-Woo, master tutor, skillfully guides the conversation to the lesson. But Da-Hae still has something on her mind. She puts down pen.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?  26.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: The teacher downstairs. Ms. Jessica. Is she really your cousin’s friend? This catches Ki-Woo off guard. He disguises it with a smi

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: She’s your girlfriend, isn’t she? Ki-Woo relaxes and laughs. He looks at Da-Hae, who is all worried and serious. She’s cute.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Come on. I just met her today.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: (pouting) She’s very pretty. Not even interested?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: She is pretty. A beauty even.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: I knew it. You are interested.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: If you were a perfect ten, maybe she would be a six? Six-point- five? A cheesy line, but Da-Hae smiles, pleased. Suddenly, she Ki-Woo’s wrist under the desk. She presses it gently, fee his pulse. A bold, unexpected move on her part. Ki-Woo stares quietly at Da-Hae. Slowly, they grow closer Lips converge. A soft, gentle kiss held through silence u They hear FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs. KI-WOoO (CONT’D) Let’s study.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: Right.  21 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yon-Kyo and Ki-Jung pass Da-Hae’s room and walk toward Da Song’s. Yon-Kyo turns to Ki-Jung, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I should tell you. He’s not good at staying in one place. (apologetic) I hope you understand--

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Ki-Jung has no expression. Nothing fazes her. Yon-Kyo hesitates before finally opening the door to reveal -- DA-SONG’S ROOM A huge clutter. Covered with Da-Song’s drawings as well a pictures of Native American tribesmen. All kinds of India themed toys. A TEEPEE TENT imported from America. Da-Song is lying on the floor with a toy arrow tucked bet his legs. Staring at the ceiling. In his own world. This also be an act.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you mind leaving?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: I don’t allow parents to sit in during lessons. Yon-Kyo is surprised. She continues to linger, but Ki-Jun stare is unwavering.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I just thought, since it’s the first day-- As you can see, the boy is a bit--

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: You should wait downstairs. Yon-Kyo finally backs down, subdued by Ki-Jung’s authorit She walks out of the room.  22 28.

dialogues.speaker: TICK TOCK TICK TOCK.
dialogues.text: Yon-Kyo and Mun-Kwang nibble on nuts as they pass time in kitchen. The dog licks Yon-Kyo’s face, which is full of a worry, curiosity. Mun-Kwang sees Yon-Kyo’s state --

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: Would you like some plum extract? I can add some honey. It’1l help you relax.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: What? Oh. Sure. Mun-Kwang walks down a narrow set of stairs to the --

dialogues.speaker: STORAGE BASEMENT
dialogues.text: Stocked with all kinds of foods, beverages, and other hou necessities. On one side is a cabinet filled with numerou GLASS JARS -- hand-extracted plum, tangerine, and fig concentrates. Mun-Kwang picks up the plum bottle and twis the tightly locked lid when -- Yon-Kyo hurtles down the stairs. YON-KYO (CONT’D) I have an idea! This is what we'll do!

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: You'll take two plum juices to Da- Song’s room. You’re not a parent so you can go in. You’ll just be delivering the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: You're right. I’11 take a quick peek and let you know how they’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Dammit. Why didn’t I think of this before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mun-Kwang and Yon-Kyo hurry back up the steps with a cup plum extract. They are startled to see -- Ki-Jung and Da-Song waiting in the kitchen, already done their lesson. Yon-Kyo tries to hide her surprise. YON-KYO (CONT’D) You guys are... done? Ki-Jung is holding a picture drawn by Da-Song. Da-Song is standing politely behind her.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Mrs. Park, will you please have a seat?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (nervous ) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Da-Song, you go up. Yon-Kyo and Mun-Kwang are stunned to see -- Da-Song obediently bowing and heading up the stairs. What Ki-Jung hands Yon-Kyo the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Da-Song drew this today. Yon-Kyo is scared. She has no idea what’s going on. Ki-Jung clocks Mun-Kwang peeking over Yon-Kyo’s shoulders

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak to you alone.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Oh, this is--

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Can you please give us a moment? Yon-Kyo’s voice falters at Ki-Jung’s ice-cold demeanor. Mun-Kwang stares hard at Ki-Jung before walking away.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mentioned earlier that I’m also studying art therapy.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember--  30.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (re: drawing) Did something happen to Da-Song when he was in first grade? Yon-Kyo yelps loudly! She quickly covers her mouth. Her h start shaking.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel a bit cautious about bringing this up -- it’s the first day after all -- but I’1l need to know what happened to Da-Song in order to truly understand him.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: When he was in first grade-- (tearful) I’m sorry. I don’t know if I can talk about this right now.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: It’s fine. We can talk about it later. Ki-Jung puts a finger on the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. This lower section is what's called the ‘schizophrenia zone’ in psychology. It contains clues about the mental state of the child. Do you see this particular shape drawn here?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I do. Yon-Kyo suddenly looks up from the drawing and stares at large framed picture on the wall. YON-KYO (CONT’D) My gosh! It’s in the other drawing too! Same spot! Ki-Jung looks back at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes. Same spot, same pattern. Yon-Kyo nods fervently. She sobs harder. horrible mother. She feels like a  31.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I see that picture everyday. Every time I eat. (sobs) I had no idea.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: You don’t have to beat yourself up. These drawings are records of Da-Song’s emotions. A black box of his soul. I’d like to try and unlock that box. But I’1l need time.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Of course. Please take as much time as you need. I can wait.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (calm) I suggest four two-hour sessions a week -- Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday. This is different from regular tutoring -- it’s art therapy -- so I would need to be compensated at a higher rate.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Of course. I understand. Ki-Jung continues her performance as multi-certified art teacher and therapist Jessica when -- We hear a car pull into the garage. Moments later, DONG-I PARK, 45, Yon-Kyo’s husband and Da-Song’s father, emerges the stairs next to the front entrance. We notice the AUTOMATED MOTION-SENSOR LIGHTS blinking abo main entrance as Dong-Ik walks in. YUN, 31, the driver, follows up with Dong-Ik’s things.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh-- Yon-Kyo wipes her tears. YON-KYO (CONT’D) Dong-Ik. Say hi to Ms. Jessica, Da-Song’s new art teacher. She just started today. (to Jessica; in English) Jessica, this is Dong-Ik.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (curt) Hello.  23 32. Dong-Ik looks tired. But even the fatigue adds to his mys and cool as a high-flying CEO. He shares a brief handshak with Ki-Jung.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Thank you for helping Da-Song. (to Yon-Kyo) Are they done for the day?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Yes, they just finished.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: (to Yun) Sorry Yun, but are you busy tonight? Would you mind taking Ms. Jessica home? I don’t want her walking down the hill alone at night. INT. DONG-IK’S CAR - DRIVING - NIGHT 23 Ki-Jung sits quietly in the back. She looks quite natural the backseat of the swanky Mercedes. Yun sneaks glances at Ki-Jung through the rearview mirror Ki-Jung’s

dialogues.speaker: YUN
dialogues.text: Where do you live, Ms. Jessica? I might as well just drive you home--

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Just drop me off at Hyehwa Station. Thank you. cold demeanor intrigues Yun instead of putting him off. He’s attracted. He tries again. Yun looks

dialogues.speaker: YUN
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter if it’s far. I’m done for the day--

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: I’ll get off at Hyehwa. out the window.

dialogues.speaker: YUN
dialogues.text: It looks like it’s about to rain. I bet the Mercedes is way better than the subway--  24 33.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) No. I’m supposed to meet my boyfriend at the station.

dialogues.speaker: YUN
dialogues.text: I see. Yun’s smile disappears. He quietly turns the steering whe Ki-Jung stares at the back of Yun’s head, thinking. Then She slowly reaches under her skirt and starts rolling dow underwear! Her eyes twinkle in the dark as she holds the removed und in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Tek plates budget Ki-Woo

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Did you drive Benzes when you were a designated driver?

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Not when I was at the designated driver service. I drove a lot of them when I was a valet.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: When were you a valet?

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: After the fried chicken and before the Taiwanese Castella. About six months, I’d say?

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Nah. It was after the Castella shop went bust. and family stack food onto their already mountainous as they move along the buffet line. They’re at a large restaurant frequented by BUS AND TAXI DRIVERS. makes sure no one is listening before --

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: We're already starting Phase Three?

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: I planted a little trap in the Mercedes. We'll see if he bites.  34.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Then it’s begun. (looking around) Father, how amazing is this? We just so happen to be eating at a buffet for drivers. How symbolic! Ki-Tek doesn’t get it but beams anyway.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: This place IS amazing! You guys eat as much as you want!

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: You're not even buying, you big bum. They are. Ki-Tek is still happy. He’s grown immune to Chung-Sook’s insults.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Here. He puts some of his meat on Ki-Woo’s plate. KI-TEK (CONT’D) Have some of this, Son.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad! (to Ki-Jung) By the way, what did you say to Mrs. Park yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: She was over the moon about you. Saying that you were a godsend. A freaking miracle FedExed from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (laughs) I just googled ‘art therapy’ and did a little improv, and she just lost her shit. Started crying like a baby. Can’t believe how gullible she is.  25 26 35. INT. DONG-IK’S CAR - DRIVING - NIGHT 25 Dong-Ik is going through some papers in the back when one under the seat. As he reaches down to grab it -- He sees a vague WHITE SHAPE beneath the passenger seat. H picks it up. A pair of women’s underwear. Ki-Jung’s. Dong-Ik looks disgusted. He stares hard at the back of Yu head before putting the underwear in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dong-Ik rushes up the garage stairs. He passes the blinki motion-sensor lights and stomps toward the --

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Something happen? Dong-Ik checks to see if the kids are around.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: It’s Yun. That son of a bitch. I found this under the car seat. Dong-Ik pulls out the panties from his pocket. Yon-Kyo gasps, shocked. Perhaps more outraged than necess

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You pay him well, don’t you? He doesn’t have money to go toa hotel? Is he saving that money for something?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s a sexual deviant? He might get off on doing it in his boss’ car. Yon-Kyo sees -- Dong-Ik is in no mood. YON-KYO (CONT’D) I’m sorry, babe. I had no idea that he was such a perv.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: I don’t care who or what he screws. That’s his business. I get it. He’s a young guy. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But why does he have to do it in my car? And why in the backseat? That’s my space. Is he trying to mark his territory? With his dirty cum stains? Son of a bitch crossed the line. Yon-Kyo doesn’t know what to do. Her husband rarely gets upset. Dong-Ik calms down and looks at the underwear.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quiet) You know what’s even weirder?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (nervous ) What?

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Don’t you see? Think about it. Yon-Kyo is freaked out of her mind.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So they have sex in the car. It’s not unusual to leave behind a few strands of hair, maybe an earring. But how do you forget your underwear?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: It’s true. You don’t just forget to put on your knickers.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: That’s why. I’m more concerned by his -- partner. Her mental state. Do you know what I mean? Dong-Ik checks the surroundings before whispering somethi Yon-Kyo’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: NOOOO--
dialogues.text: (turning pale) Like methamphetamine? Cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Shhhh!

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: What do we do? If they find some kind of white powder in your car, we're all doomed!  37.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Calm down, babe. Relax. We don’t want to go too far. Not yet. For now it’s just a suspicion. A well-founded one. As the Parks continue to fret over the panties, CAMERA BO

dialogues.speaker: TO REVEAL --
dialogues.text: Ki-Jung standing on the stairs with her bag, listening to conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can’t even take something like this to the police. And it would look ridiculous if I tried to interrogate him. What would I say? “Yun, did you have sexual intercourse in my car?” (then) That’s why I was thinking--

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Yes, dear.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: You have to take care of this. Come up with some kind of bland, harmless reason. Let him go quietly. Don’t even mention the panties. Or the intercourse.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I understand. We don’t want the neighborhood birds gossiping about the Parks’ driver sexing up the boss’ car.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Exactly. Our names will forever be linked with his disgusting behavior. Yon-Kyo nods, then thinks.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: You don’t think Yun would post something online, do you? Go ona Twitter vendetta? He could announce to the whole world that he was unfairly fired by a famous tech CEO.  27 38.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: We'll pay him severance. Enough to keep him quiet. Just choose your words carefully when you let him go. Then we’ll be fine. Just then Ki-Jung starts walking down the stairs. Steppin loudly so the Parks can hear. Yon-Kyo leaps out of her seat. Dong-Ik quickly hides the underwear and puts on an awkward smile.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (smiling) Are you guys done? How was Da- Song today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yon-Kyo and Ki-Jung walk toward the gate. Yon-Kyo sidles Ki-Jung, acting friendlier than usual.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Ms. Jessica, I wanted to ask. The other night, when Yun took you home...

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: This may sound weird but-- Did anything happen that night?

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: No. I went straight home.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Good, good. (relieved) That’s good to hear.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Such a nice man. I asked him to drop me off at Hyehwa Station, but he kept insisting that he would take me home.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (raising her voice) So the bastard went to your house? At night? He knows where you live?

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: No. I just got off at Hyehwa.  39.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (sighs) Thank God. You did the right thing. (English) Nice, Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Did something happen to him? Yon-Kyo opens the gate.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: He, well-- He won’t be working for us anymore. There was a bit of an incident. You don’t need to know the details.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: That’s too bad. He seemed like a nice man.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: You're so precious, Ms. Jessica. So innocent. You still have a lot to learn about this world. Ki-Jung stifles her laughter as she walks down the steps. sees Mun-Kwang walking back home with the Parks’ THREE DO the distance. Yon-Kyo waves at them. YON-KYO (CONT’D) (sighs) We used to like him too. We were excited to have a driver who was young and hip.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: I thought most people preferred older drivers.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s true. Older drivers tend to drive more carefully. They’re more sophisticated.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: My uncle had a driver who was like that. Mr. Kim. A real gentleman. Such a kind man. We used to follow him like an uncle.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Really?  28 40.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes. He was such a warm and kindhearted person. Unfortunately, my uncle was transferred to Chicago and had to let Mr. Kim go. I don’t know what he’s doing these days--

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I’m very interested in this person, Ms. Jessica. Do you think I could meet him? As you can see, it’s becoming harder and harder for me to trust people. I won’t hire anyone unless they’re recommended by people I absolutely, positively trust. I just have a feeling he could be a great candidate since you grew up with him and all. Mun-Kwang walks within earshot and hears the conversation curiosity is piqued. The dogs wag their tails and swarm Yon-Kyo.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Would you like to meet him? (English) Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (English) I am deadly serious. (Korean) I think this is the best way to hire people. Through people I trust. It’s like a, what should I call it-- Yon-Kyo makes a peculiar hand gesture. YON-KYO (CONT’D) ‘Belt of Trust.’ As the scene’s THEME MUSIC (titled “The Belt of Trust”) b to play, we cut to the inside of a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Tek is in the driver seat. We don’t know whose car thi or where we are. He tries buckling the seat belt. Presses various buttons on the instrument panel.  29 30 41. Ki-Woo is in the backseat, telling his father to try this that. When some people approach, the pair hop out of the and move onto another one, revealing that -- We are inside a large MERCEDES DEALERSHIP in the middle o Gangnam. Ki-Tek and Ki-Woo continue to explore brand new Benzes, s quality father and son time. INT. DONG-IK’S COMPANY - CEO OFFICE - DAY 29 An office overlooking Seoul’s soaring skyscrapers. Dong-I in a meeting with his HOD’s. He suddenly looks up at the side of the glass wall where -- Ki-Tek is sitting in a chair, waiting patiently to be see

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: (mouthing) Sorry. I'll. Be. Right. With. You.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, sir. (mouthing & gesturing) Take. Your. Time. INT. DONG-IK’S CAR - DRIVING - LATE AFTERNOON 30

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: This isn’t a test or anything so you don’t have to be nervous. I just wanted to get out of the office. I was dying in there. Ki-Tek is in the driver seat. ("The Belt of Trust” continues under the scene.)

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I understand. You’re surrounded by people all day. I’m sure you want some peace in the car. Ki-Tek turns off the car’s navigation.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Thank you. You must know your way around the city.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Every highway, road, and alley south of the DMZ. When you do this for 30 years, it becomes second nature.  31 42.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: I admire people who work in one profession their whole lives.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: It’s a simple job really. But I take pride in it. Every morning, I go on a journey. With a father, a CEO, or just a solitary man walking through life. It’s a sort of companionship--

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: That’s how I’ve treated my job for the past 30 years. How time flies. The words drip with cheese, but somehow they sound heartf when Ki-Tek says it with his humble stammer. As the MUSIC crests toward a climax -- Ki-Tek turns the wheel, making a smooth left turn.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Exquisite corner-work. I can feel your experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MUSIC continues -- SLOW MOTION of Ki-Jung gracefully, rhythmically walking d the stairs. She finds -- Mun-Kwang dozing off at the dining table. Lightly snoring Dogs circling her feet. Ki-Jung stares for a long moment. As she walks past the d room -- She SLAPS the wall loudly, shocking Mun-Kwang out of her daydream. Mun-Kwang acts like she wasn’t sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: She’s an old fox. She acts like she’s Mrs. Park’s sister.  43. 32 INT. MANSION - DA-HAE’S ROOM - NIGHT 32 Mun-Kwang leaves a plate of fruits for Ki-Woo and Da-Hae. Ki-Woo stares at her intently as she walks out. KI-woo (V.0.) She’s been in the house the longest. Longer than the family. She used to work for the previous owner, the architect Namgoong Hyunja, who recommended her to the Parks when he moved to France. Told them she takes great care of the house and so on--

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: So she survived an ownership change.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: (nods ) It’s a made job. Of course she won't just let go.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: If we want to extract her, we’1ll need to do some prep work.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: That’s right. We need a plan. Chung-Sook, Ki-Woo, and Ki-Jung are sitting at the corner table. We notice the tacky Pizza Time logo everywhere. The Pizza Shop Owner (from Scene 4) begrudgingly brings a combination pizza over to the table. She hates that she h serve these losers.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Hey, how about some more hot sauce here? The Owner picks up a hot sauce from the other table and d it in front of Chung-Sook. Chung-Sook mouths ‘bitch’ as the Owner walks away. Ki-Woo studies the hot sauce. He picks it up and squirts drops on a blank napkin, as if testing something.  34 35 36 37

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: There’s something that Da-Hae told me. INT. MANSION - DA-HAE’S ROOM - NIGHT 34

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: I’m so sick of apples. I want peaches.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Then why don’t you just ask for them? Da-Hae is griping about the fruit plate Mun-Kwang brought picks up an apple slice and lovingly feeds it to Ki-Woo.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: (pouting) We can’t have peaches. It’s a forbidden fruit in our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Jung picks up a PEACH from the fruit section. She hold in the sunlight and carefully examines the soft fuzz surrounding it. KI-WoO (V.0.) The housekeeper has a severe peach allergy. If she even goes near a peach, she’1ll turn red and start hyperventilating. Full-on asthma attack. Does everything but kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using a sharp razor, Ki-Woo meticulously shaves off the f around the peach. He deposits the fuzz in a transparent p cap. HAUNTING, NERVE-SCRAPING MUSIC plays underneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo walks out of the house after another lesson. He bo Mun-Kwang, who is in the yard handing out treats to the d Ki-Woo takes out his pen as he passes Mun-Kwang. He opens cap and gently pours peach fuzz over her shoulders.  38 39 40 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Woo has just walked out of the gate when he hears VIOL COUGHING from inside. It’s Mun-Kwang. He casually walks down the hill as the coughing echoes throughout the neighborhood, creating a discordant harmon the MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mun-Kwang is on the bench talking on her phone. Still cov in red spots. She’s unaware that -- Ki-Tek is watching her from several feet away. He takes o his phone and snaps a selfie, making sure to include Mun- in the background.

dialogues.speaker: MUN-KWANG
dialogues.text: (into her phone) It was the worst one I ever had. I was sure I was going to die. No. I’m telling you. No peaches for miles. That’s what I’m saying. It’s driving me nuts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yon-Kyo carries a bunch of shopping bags out of the depar store. Ki-Tek is waiting at the Mercedes. He opens the trunk and Yon-Kyo’s bags in. When he’s done, he continues to linger hesitates before taking out his phone.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Mrs. Park. I, um, I didn’t know if this was worth mentioning, but I wanted to make sure. He shows Yon-Kyo a photo on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This person behind me. Is that--

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: What-- Hey, that’s Mun-Kwang!

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: So it was her. I didn’t quite remember her face. I’d only seen her a couple of times when I went up to the house.  46.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Where is this from? Is that a hospital?

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Yes. I was at the hospital the other day for an annual check-up. I was taking a selfie to send my wife when I saw her behind me. Yon-Kyo looks closely at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Looks like she’s talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Yes, see-- I didn’t mean to, but I ended up overhearing--

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: (stammering) I, uh, didn’t mean to eavesdrop, but I happened to be right there, and unfortunately, uh, overheard everything--

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Cut, stop right there. Dad, you're overdoing it. The worrying thing. Tone it down. I can tell you're acting. Ki-Tek rehearses his ‘scene,’ holding a piece of paper wi lines. KI-WoO (CONT’D) Action!

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I really didn’t mean to. I was right there, and I just happened to overhear.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (interested) What did you hear?  43 44 45 46 Ki-Tek looks at Yon-Kyo through the rearview mirror. a hesitant beat before opening his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I should say--

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: (acting) I heard her say that she was -- diagnosed with tuberculosis!

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (stunned) Tuberculosis! Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: What was it-- “Active pulmonary tuberculosis.” She was talking on the phone, and she seemed very upset. Like she was angry at herself.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: (female voice) I didn’t even know tuberculosis was still a thing.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I didn’t even know tuberculosis was still a thing.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Neither did I. I remember years ago we used to buy those seals for Christmas, but I thought it was all over. You should look it up. Korea still has the highest tuberculosis rate among OECD countries.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: I can’t believe that Mun-Kwang-- (emotional) How could she not tell me? I can’t-- 47. He takes 43 44 45 46  47 48 49 48.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure if I should say anything, but I felt like you should know. I mean, she was just going about her business like everything was normal. There are young children in the house. Da- Song is only ten. And this woman, with her tuberculosis, is in the kitchen making food and touching the dishes--

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Stop! Yon-Kyo goes into a shrieking fit. YON-KYO (CONT’D) Please! No more! INT. MANSION - DA-SONG’S ROOM - LATE AFTERNOON 47 The art lesson is in progress. Ki-Jung has Da-Song in her She touches Da-Song’s face with her cheek as she looks at drawing. Ki-Jung’s cell phone DINGS. It’s a text from Ki-Tek -- “ETA 3 min. Get ready.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUSPENSEFUL MUSIC builds as Ki-Jung descends the stairs. she removes her hand from her pocket, we see that it’s co in soft PEACH FUZZ. The fuzz glistens in the afternoon sunlight as Ki-Jung walks down to the --

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Where she opens the fridge and removes a bottle of water. Mun-Kwang comes over and hands her a glass. As Ki-Jung ta the glass, she casually wipes the peach fuzz on Mun-Kwang hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our first time inside the garage. Ki-Tek carries the many shopping bags up the stairs. Yon-Kyo follows when -- She hears VIOLENT COUGHING coming from upstairs.  50 51 52 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yon-Kyo is appalled to see -- Mun-Kwang coughing like a sick dog as she comes out to gr her and Ki-Tek. Mun-Kwang tries to take the bags from Ki- but the coughing becomes unbearable, and she runs to the

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: She tries to stifle her cough with a napkin. No use. She throws the napkin in the trash and rushes to the bathroom Yon-Kyo is horrified. It’s like watching Ebola spread in of her eyes. Ki-Tek just stands there, staring quietly at the discarde napkin in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: If you find an opportunity -- do it. Just like we practiced. It'll be the cherry on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-Tek leaves Yon-Kyo behind and walks over to the kitche removes his hand from his pocket and reaches into the tra can, at which point we cut to -- A PIZZA TIME HOT SAUCE PACKET hidden in Ki-Tek’s palm. Ki-Tek quickly squirts the red sauce on the napkin. KI-WoO (V.0.) Our bloody finale. A terrified Yon-Kyo watches as Ki-Tek removes the ‘bloody napkin from the trash. kKi-Tek grimly holds it up in fron her. Yon-Kyo becomes dizzy. She closes her eyes to keep hersel from fainting. The MUSIC that continued through the last several scenes “The Belt of Trust” -- comes to a dramatic end.  53 54 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more music. The house is quiet. We see a text from Yon-Kyo on Ki-Tek’s phone -- “2nd floor sauna. Make sure she doesn’t see you.” Ki-Tek looks around before quietly treading up the stairs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, phone-booth-sized sauna situated at the end of t hallway between the dressing room and bathroom. As soon as Ki-Tek walks in, Yon-Kyo shuts the door and pu down the roller shades. They are now inches away from eac other in the tight space. Light seeps in from outside, illuminating Yon-Kyo’s bloodshot eyes and smeared makeup.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Mr. Kim, you have to promise you won’t tell my husband.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: He can’t find out that I’ve been keeping that walking lung disease around the kids this whole time. He’1l kill me.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Mrs. Park. (then) I don’t want to step out of line, but I had a request as well. See, I have nothing personal against the housekeeper. (whispering) I only acted out of a moral obligation to protect the health and safety of the public. I wouldn’t want Mr. Park to think that I’m some kind of tattletale--

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Don’t worry. I’m not even going to mention the tuberculosis to Mun-Kwang. I'’11 come up with a completely unrelated reason. Let her go quietly.  55 56 57 51.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (sighs) It’s the best way. I’ve done it before.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Well, I trust your judgment. Ki-Tek puts out his hand, as if he wants to officialize t top-secret deal. They are sharing the most awkward handshake in the world Yon-Kyo suddenly cringes.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Did you wash your hands, Mr. Kim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The backyard seen through kitchen windows. Strong winds s the trees. A storm is on route. Yon-Kyo is seated at the patio table with Mun-Kwang. Her is cold as she calmly explains something to her soon-to-b former housekeeper. Mun-Kwang’s face gradually turns dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mun-Kwang carries a large bag down the hill. Still in disbelief. Devastated. Her hair dances wildly in the roug wind. The sky is getting darker. Mun-Kwang keeps looking back at the house as she walks aw She stops and stares at the firmly closed gate for a long

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s raining outside.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Mr. Kim, do you know a place where I can get some good short ribs? Somewhere not too far.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Of course.  52. Ki-Tek turns the wheel and switches lanes. KI-TEK (CONT’D) You'll be eating out tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Yes. I suddenly had a craving for juicy short ribs. Since I can’t have them at home now. Ki-Tek makes an effortless U-turn across the large, eight road. The raindrops on the window swerve diagonally.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiles) Our housekeeper used to make the best short ribs.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: You mean the lady who just quit yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: She was with us for a long time. I don’t know why she suddenly left. Mrs. Park wouldn’t even tell me. I mean, there’s no shortage of housekeepers looking for work so I guess we can just hire another one. But it’s a real pity. She was a great lady.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: She took care of all the little things in the house. And she was a tremendous cook. Most importantly, she never crossed the line. If there’s one thing I hate, it’s people who cross the line. Well, I guess she did have one flaw. (laughs) She was a big eater. Ate twice as much as other people. But I suppose she worked twice as hard to make up for that.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I guess Mrs. Park will need to find a new housekeeper soon.  53.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: (nods ) Or the house will descend into chaos. I guarantee she won’t be able to survive a week without one. Shambles, I tell you. My clothes will start smelling-- (laughs) Mrs. Park definitely wins the worst homemaker award. Doesn’t know her way around a vacuum, and her cooking is just -- abysmal!

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: But... you still love her, don’t you? Ki-Tek’s suddenly serious comment catches Dong-Ik off gua Silence. Then Dong-Ik starts laughing. Hard.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Of course I love her! I don’t know what else you’d call this.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Then maybe you should look at this-- Ki-Tek removes a business card from his pocket and hands Dong-Ik. On beautiful ivory-colored stock, only the name, “The Car printed in elegant typography. No number. No address.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: The Care? What is this?

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: I just found out about them recently too. It’s a membership- based total care company. Catering to families of VIP’s like yourself. They provide maids, in- home caregivers, also drivers like myself. From what I hear, they select only the best. The most experienced workers.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: Looks very nice. Dong-Ik flips the card to the other side.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The design is gorgeous. How did you learn about this company, Mr. Kim?  58 54.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: They called me about working for them. I guess I’m one of the more experienced drivers around, so they wanted to recruit me. I turned them down because I was already scheduled to meet you. I see.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: (nods ) Well, I’m honored that you chose me over such a reputable company. I am forever grateful, Mr. Kim! Dong-Ik laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: (laughs) You're being ridiculous, sir. They’re laughing, but there’s a subtle underlying tension between the two men. There’s still a ‘line’ that Dong-Ik won’t cross. He suddenly drops his smile. Well,

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: then. I guess I’1l just give this to Mrs. Park.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Yes, you should. But don’t say I gave it to you. (smiles) You should tell her that you looked it up yourself.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: (laughs) Good idea! That’s sure to earn me some points. Thank you, Mr. Kim.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: They’re membership-only, so I don’t think they have a website or anything. There’s a consultation number in the back--

dialogues.speaker: RING RING RING.
dialogues.text: Ki-Jung picks up an OLD FLIP PHONE with “The Care” business card taped on front. She sounds like Welcoming. a completely different person. Sweet.  59 60 55.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Thank you for calling The Care. This is senior advisor Yeo Myung- Sun. How may I help you? Chung-Sook and Ki-Tek watch Ki-Jung as they eat breakfast

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: She could have won an Oscar if she became an actress.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: She has a nice voice, doesn’t she? Just like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yon-Kyo has the phone on speaker. She has disposable kitc gloves on and is generally floundering in the kitchen, overloading the dishwasher and sterilizing the ‘disease-r pots and pans in an oversized steamer.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (into the phone) I heard I need to sign up for a membership.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: That’s correct. We are a membership-only service. If you aren’t currently a member I can guide you through the steps to become one.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Sure, okay.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Do you have a pen? I can give you the list of forms you need to submit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fully transformed Chung-Sook sits at the white patio ta with Yon-Kyo. Classy hairstyle. Tasteful makeup. Yon-Kyo goes through Chung-Sook’s papers, especially focu on her doctor’s note.  61 56. Just then a WHITE BUTTERFLY flits by Chung-Sook’s face, i wings playfully bouncing off the bright summer light. Over the idyllic scene, a beautiful ARIA begins to flow--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MUSIC continues -- STEADICAM SHOT -- We glide up the stairs, first following Chung-Sook’s feet then rising up to shoulder height, trac her from behind as she walks down the second floor hallwa She opens the door to -- DA-HAE’S ROOM We follow Chung-Sook as she walks in and sets down a plat fruits in front of Da-Hae and Ki-Woo.

dialogues.speaker: DA-HAE
dialogues.text: Yay! Peaches!

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Please have some too, Mr. Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma’am. Chung-Sook pinches Ki-Woo’s earlobe while Da-Hae is not looking. Ki-Woo nearly jumps. Chung-Sook just smiles and walks out of the room. We continue to follow her as she p down the hall and enters -- DA-SONG’S ROOM Where we see the TEEPEE in the corner. The flap opens and Jung peeks out to see who it is. Da-Song is tightly cuddl between her arms drawing a picture. He looks at Chung-Soo embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Next time just knock and leave the food outside.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: Sorry--

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: Please don’t come in during the lesson. Chung-Sook scoffs. She mouths ‘JUST EAT THE DAMN PEACHES’ she hands over the plate. She looks around at the drawing the room. Not impressed. She steps out into the --  57.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: We hear DONG-IK arriving downstairs. Da-Song hears it too bolts out of the room and flies past Chung-Sook toward th

dialogues.speaker: DA-SONG
dialogues.text: Daddy! Did you get the walkie?

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Da-Song! Lesson’s not over yet!

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: This guy. That’s all you think about, isn’t it? Camping. Dong-Ik picks up Da-Song and holds him tightly. CAMERA CIRCLES AROUND THEM and shows -- Ki-Tek emerging from the garage with a bunch of boxes. Br new camping supplies. On top is a WALKIE-TALKIE box.

dialogues.speaker: DA-SONG
dialogues.text: Wow! T-667! Dope!

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: What's all this stuff? We just bought camping gear last year.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: These are different. Might as well complete the collection. Da-Song has already opened the walkie-talkie box. He also through the other items -- CAMPFIRE SUPPLIES, AN AXE FOR CHOPPING FIREWOOD... As Ki-Tek walks out, he quickly feels up Chung-Sook’s beh Chung-Sook giggles to herself as she goes to the kitchen The long STEADICAM SHOT is about to come to a glorious en after showing the semi-basement’s family complete and successful infiltration of the Park mansion. Wait. Not ye Da-Song suddenly starts sniffing the air. He runs over to Chung-Sook and shoves his nose in her belly, startling he greatly. Da-Song then darts over to Ki-Tek and shoves his nose in pant leg.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Da-Song! What’s wrong with you?  62 58.

dialogues.speaker: DA-SONG
dialogues.text: Same smell. They smell exactly the same! Ki-Tek and Chung-Sook freeze. Yon-Kyo, embarrassed, roughly pushes Da-Song away.

dialogues.speaker: YON-KYO
dialogues.text: Stop talking nonsense and go up to your room. Ms. Jessica is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: DA-SONG
dialogues.text: That's weird. Ms. Jessica has the same smell. Dong-Ik laughs awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: DONG-IK
dialogues.text: (to Ki-Tek) He’s a little out there. They all laugh, but no one is laughing inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table teems with food. We notice the viewing stone displayed prominently in the middle. An interesting decor choice. Ki-Tek is cooking ribs and mushrooms on an electric skill when he suddenly smells his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: He scared me, the little punk. Does this mean we all have to use different soaps?

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: Maybe we should all wash our clothes with different detergent. Different fabric softeners too.

dialogues.speaker: CHUNG-SOOK
dialogues.text: You mean I have to wash all of your clothes separately? Fuck no.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG
dialogues.text: (expressionless) It won’t work. It’s the basement smell. Ki-Woo is blank.  59.

dialogues.speaker: KI-JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The smell won’t go away unless we leave this place. Truth bomb. They all fall silent at the brutal reality ch and for a while we only hear the sizzling of the grill. Ki-Tek picks up his Sapporo and tries to change the subje

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Forget about that. This is a good problem to have. Think about our lives before. It’s a dog-eat-dog world out there. Hundreds of college graduates compete for a security guard job for Chrissake. (emotional ) Not us. We are all gainfully employed.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
dialogues.text: You're right, Father. Cheers!

dialogues.speaker: KI-TEK
dialogues.text: Sure we may not be getting six- figure salaries, but it’s no small amount if you combine our wages. The Parks are investing a great part of their fortune in our family. So let us give thanks to Mr. Park, our generous employer. A great man. And how can I forget Min-Hyuk! How lucky that our son is friends with such a thoughtful young man. It’s all because of him that-- FUCK! Do they always have to ruin the moment? The family members all turn toward -- The window, which is being rattled by a robust stream of A SHORT, BARELY STANDING DRUNK MAN is relieving himself i corner.

dialogues.speaker: KI-WOO
